item.title: Open Evening - 30th August
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded:
Are you a photographer? Have you thought of taking up photography?

If the answer is YES to either of these questions, then why not come along to Bromsgrove Photographic Society Open Evening on Tuesday 30th August at Stoke Heath Community Arts Centre, Stoke Heath, Bromsgrove. B60 4JR 7:30 for 8:00pm start

Come along and have a chat, meet our members, have a coffee.

Why not bring your camera(s) and tripod, if you have one.

We will have Still Life, light tents, and a portrait session set up for you to experiment with. If you have any technical questions about equipment, printers or what camera/lens to buy, we will do our best to give you answers.

We have members who are interested in film and darkroom work, nature, landscape, portrait, monochrome and even pinhole photography.

If you would like more information please contact

Peter Garnett, Vice Chairman 07842 170231 or e-mail vice.chairman@bromsgroveps.co.uk

Check out our web site at www.bromsgroveps.co.uk

item.title: Competition Rules
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded:
(Revised March 2012) Monthly Competition Rules There are six classes, which are:
  1. Prints
    1. Mono Prints
    2. General Colour Prints
    3. Nature Prints
  2. Projected
    1. Mono
    2. General Colour
    3. Nature
There will be 4 Print and 4 Projected Competitions in each season. The Competition Secretary will be pleased to answer any questions on the following or on any other matters relating to the Competitions. General Rules (these apply to all competitions)
  1. Entries will only be accepted from fully paid up members.
  2. All entries must be photographs (made by the action of light of any wavelength on a sensitive surface) of which the entrant holds the copyright.
  3. Mono is defined as Monochrome base with up to one added colour e.g. full sepia plus one colour, but not monochrome base, partially sepia toned plus one colour. This rule will be interpreted with common sense.
  4. Members may enter up to three photographs in each class. Each photographs class and the name of the entrant must be identified.
  5. Any entry may be used by the Society for publicity purposes and will be made available on request for inter-club competitions.
  6. A photograph may be entered a second time in the same class provided it has not been awarded Commended or above in any year.
  7. A photograph of the same subject and likeness must not be entered in the same competition by the same photographer.
  8. Photographs of a similar likeness may only be entered in a competition if the title indicates that there is more than one photograph e.g. Flower 1, Flower 2 etc.
  9. A record of placings made by judges will be kept by the Competition Secretary for appropriate awards to be made.
  10. All points count towards the two Aggregate Awards for Prints and Projected but only the best score in each month will count towards the six Class Competitions.
  11. All entries must be handed in on the correct night, clearly identified with the authors name, class and title. Any entry not complying with these requirements will be returned.
  12. The Competition Secretary may use his/her discretion to waive or amend competition rules where appropriate.
  13. Whilst the Society will take every reasonable care, the liability for any damage to photographs shall be the entrants.
Print Rules
  1. Mono and colour prints may be either home or trade processed.
  2. Prints must be mounted and no larger than 20 inches by 16 inches including mount.
Digital Projection Rules
  1. Photographic files must be in JPG format with minimum compression and shall be a maximum of 1400 pixels wide or 1050 pixels high.
  2. The images must be in a single layer in RGB mode and the sRGB colourspace.
  3. File names must be in the format [Projection order][single space][Title].jpg e.g. 2 My Photo.jpg or 3 A Duck.jpg no dashes, underscores etc between the number and your title please. Use capital letters and spaces in the title where they would normally appear; and do not type .jpg after the title (as .jpg is inserted automatically by the software).
  4. Files should be submitted in relevant folders entitled Mono, Colour or Nature.
  5. Entries may be made on any suitable medium, including by email to the Competition Secretary. In the case of email, the Competition Secretary will always send a receipt stating the number of readable files received.
  6. Files will be deleted from the computer after a competition if the entrant so requires.
Natural History Rules
  1. Entries depicting cultured plants, domesticated animals or preserved specimens are not eligible; neither should any manipulation which alters the truth of the photographic statement be entered.
Scoring System All Classes Judges will award placings in all classes and points will be as follows:
First Place 7 points
Second Place 6 points
Third Place 5 points
Highly Commended 4 points
Commended 3 points
Unplaced 2 points
Annual Competition Rules The Annual Open Competition is held towards the end of each season.There will be six sections. These will be the same as for the Monthly Competitons.
  1. Each entrant may submit up to three photographs in each of the six sections.
  2. Each entrant must have submitted at least one entry into a section of one of the current seasons Monthly Competitions to be eligible to submit an entry into that section of the Annual Open.
  3. Entries may have been submitted in previous Monthly Competitions or may be new work. Under no circumstances may an entry have received an award (Commended or above) in any previous Annual Open competition.
  4. No entry may be the same or similar to another entry from the same entrant in another section of the Annual Open. Other than as stated above, the rules of Monthly Competitions will apply (e.g. definition of Nature; format of projected digital photographs; etc).
  5. The interpretation of these rules will be at the discretion of the Competition Secretary but, in the event of any dispute, the Committee will decide based on such evidence they see fit to obtain.
Panel Competiton Rules In the event that a Panels Competition is held during a season, the following rules will apply. There will be two sections:
  • Print Panels
  • Digitally Projected Panels
  1. Entrants should note that there will be no separate Nature section(s) but Nature panels may be submitted in either of the two sections.
  2. Entrants should also note that a collage of a number of different photographs amalgamated into, essentially, one different photograph will not constitute a panel, however, the appropriate number of such photographs will be considered to be a panel.
  3. A Print Panel will comprise three prints with a single, collective title. Each print will indicate its orientation and position within the panel. No prints dimensions shall exceed 20 x 16.
  4. A Digitally Projected Panel will comprise three or more photographs arranged within a file of no more than 1400 pixels wide by 1050 pixels high.
  5. Each entrant may submit up to three panels in each section.
  6. Under no circumstances may an entry have received an award (Commended or above) in any previous Panels competition.
  7. No entry may be the same or similar to another entry from the same entrant in another section of the Panels competition.
  8. Other than as stated above, the rules of Monthly Competitions will apply (e.g. format of projected digital photographs; etc).
  9. The interpretation of these rules will be at the discretion of the Competition Secretary but, in the event of any dispute, the Committee will decide based on such evidence they see fit to obtain.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded:
Background Bromsgrove Photographic Society was founded in 1950 by a group of enthusiastic amateur photographers. It continues to promote and support photography as an interest and hobby to it's members. The society has an active membership of approximately 50 members and supports both film and digital photography. There is a varied and active programme of meetings including talks by professional as well as experienced amateur photographers, both print and projected image competitions and studio sessions. These form a winter programme running from September to the end of May. The society also organises a full summer programme of local and more distant visits and outings to encourage the development of all aspects of outdoor photography. This programme runs from the beginning of June to the end of August. Message from the Chairman If you have got to these web pages you may well have been looking for a local photographic club or you may have got here accidentally. Whichever way, it is a fact of modern life that photography has become almost an integral part of our lives today. Whether it is with your camera phone, compact digital camera or a DSLR we take more and more pictures of things around us. Whether you take pictures for your own interest, to share with family or to share with friends on a web site we all like to produce the best we can and derive a lot of pleasure from our pictures. Bromsgrove Photographic Society is a friendly group of enthusiastic amateur photographers. Don't be put off thinking that everybody is an expert, far from it. We have a wide range of experience and expertise. Members enjoy most forms of photography, nature, portrait and studio work, landscape and still life. Most members use digital cameras of one type or another, compacts, compact system cameras and DSLRs. Camera phones have also been known to be used and film is also still used. Come along, on a Tuesday evening, and visit one of our meetings, you will find the programme in these pages. The lectures, competition nights and studio sessions are all interesting and enjoyable. We have a program of instructional sessions planned and you should find tips on how to improve your own photography from all sessions. If this sounds like what you were looking for then why not come along on and join us. If it is the summer programme all are also welcome. You may want to check with one of the listed addresses for location and get a weather check. Peter Garnett Chairman Bromsgrove Photographic Society The Committee - 2012 / 2013 Officers and Committee Members

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Dear Sir/Madam
I'm Udayan Sankar Pal, a photographer residing in Visakhapatnam, India.
The reason I am sending this mail to you is because we have created an Archive of Photography Exhibitions. Aim of this Archive is to keep records of the exhibitions held worldwide & make this archive as resource for research. We do NOT use this archive for commercial purposes. We are collecting since 2002 & the archive has more than 5000+ brochures in its collection from around the world.
To this effect we would like your help. We would appreciate it very much if you could send us the brochures/ flyers/ synopsis/ invitation cards of your past, ongoing or soon to be conducted photographic exhibitions.
You can visit our website at http://ape.threedots.in for more information. Kindly revert if you have any queries, I will be happy to answer them.
Our address: Archive of Photography Exhibition 3-122/5 Adarsha Nagar Visakhapatnam-530040, INDIA
Looking forward for your help and contribution to enrich this archive.
Regards, Udayan S Pal.

item.title: A Great Open Evening
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded: Last night's open evening was a great success. We had a good number of potential new members come to the event - some were old friends, somebeginnersand some who may well be winning our monthly competitions soon! We set up our new lightingequipmenton the stage to allow people to experiment with. There were several still life set ups around the room. Our member malcyL has posted his results from one of these below. But most importantly, it was a great opportunity to chat to people who share our passion for photography. We hope some of them will join us.

item.title: Chris Weston - with his talk, Animals on the Edge at Stourbridge PS
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded: Stourbridge Photographic Society are holding a lecture on Thursday 6th October : Animals on the Edge by Chris Weston. Chris is a well-known wildlife/Landscape photographer and conservationist, who many of our members will already know of. If you havent heard of Chris, you can visit his website: www.chrisweston.uk.com The cost is 3.00 per head, which is the normal visitor fee. This also includes refreshments.

item.title: Model Night - Leah
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded: Last Tuesday (27th September) was the clubs first model night of the season. We were lucky enough to be taking photographs of Leah Axl from Gloucester. Here is here websitehttp://www.leahaxlmodel.co.uk. This was the first time we used our newcontinous lights (as opposed to studio flash) which removed any problems with the flash notfiring and made it possible for more than one photographer to take pictures at a time.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Here is a picture of Leah from one of our members "blunderbus68" on Flickr.
Great shot Pete - well done.
Hi, This is the best one I got of Leah on Tuesday. This was the first time I have shot a proffesional model, so just a standard pose this time!
Excellent work Pete, slight niggle maybe a little more detail around the hat....?

Great shot Andy - it deserves the nice comments it's got on Flickr.
Nice detail in the hair and the hat. You've controlled the nose shadow too.
I would try and tone down that orange behind her head. I tried to get it out of my shots before taking them! :-) I believe we have/will be ordering some different backgrounds.
Here is one of my shots - "The Model".

Hi Malcolm. Thanks for the comments. Yes I thought the orange was a bit strong... So should have fixed it realy! I didnt notice it when shooting, too busy concentrating on Leah!... I will next time though!
Nice picture. Good removal of the background. ;-) That red lipstick was asking for this treatment.
Here's another picture, added into our members gallery rather than Flickr this time.
Nice one Mal, I concur with Malc Regards Pete

item.title: An Evening with Ben Osborne
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded:
At 7.30pmonMonday 14thNovemberThe Rotary Club of Walsall are hosting anEvening with Ben Osborneat the Forest Arts Centre in Walsall.

Dog days Lion Nights

Ben was the winner of the Shell Wildlife Photographer of the Year award in 2007 - and in this illustrated talk he takes you behind-the-scenes on two filming expeditions to northern Botswana with the BBC natural history series "Planet Earth". The tour starts in the Okavango Delta where the team spent weeks on the trail of one of Africas rarest large predators, the African Hunting Dog. As well as photographing the dogs, Ben joined the camera crews as they filmed many other wildlife sequences, an experience which provided some wonderful opportunities for wildlife photography in the spectacular landscapes of this unique environment. The second expedition was to Savuti, a dry savannah region where life gets extremely tough in the October dry season. Many animals move out at this time of year but the elephants stay. So does a pride of 30 lions. Elephants are dominant to the lions in the daytime but things change after dark when a lion pride of this size becomes a serious threat to the elephants. The crew joined this feline menace day and night for a month - with dramatic, and occasionally unpredictable, consequences. Audio-visual sequences, featuring music by the Soweto String Quartet, celebrate the stunning wildlife and landscapes of the Okavango Delta and provide a close-up view of the animals which struggle to survive in the parched landscape of Savuti. Tickets are priced at 10 each and are available online from the following website:http://www.codsallphotographic.com/html/rotary.html The evening starts at 7.30pm and a bar is available during the interval. The website of the Forest Arts Centre where you can find location maps etc is at:http://www.whatsonwalsall.co.uk/forestartscentre/default.asp?home=true Tickets for this event are being sold via Codsall Photographic (Rotary Member Chris Nutt) on a non-profit basis. All proceeds from this event are destined for our Presidents nominated charities:Walsall Hospice,The Midlands Air Ambulance-and other Rotary charities

item.title: Macro Practical Workshop with John Kirk
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded: A few weeks ago we were visited by John Kirk who gave us an excellent talk on macro photography. After the talk we had a practical session where we all had a chance to take pictures of some very colourful caterpillars. One of our members, Pheebie46, has posted the following two pictures from the evening on her Flickr stream.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A few weeks ago we were visited by John Kirk who gave us an excellent talk on macro photography...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Two excellent images, the top capture is absolutely spot on, wonderful colours/ dof, if only mine were that good, well done.

There are now a few more caterpillar pictures by Jill Howe in the members gallery.
You'll find them here:
http://www.bromsgroveps.co.uk/bps_jalbum/Members%20G%20to%20R/Jill%20Howe/index.html#Caterpillar 2.JPG

item.title: 29th National Open Exhibition
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded: Today (19th November) is Bromsgrove Photographic Society's 29th National Open Exhibition. Members were busy setting up the exhibition late last night. Here is a picture showing the room with some of the pictures already on the wall. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="600" caption="29th National Open Exhibition - Setting Up"][/caption] The whiskey bottle on the table is one of the prizes in the raffle - unfortunately it wasn't there to help the members get through the evening! ;-) The exhibition is open today only - 19th November, from 12pm to 5pm and again from 6pm throughout the evening. The award ceremony is at 7:30pm with a show of projected images at 8pm. Admission for the afternoon session is 2. Evening admission is 4. Students and under 18's are free. Come and see the exhibition at Stoke Heath Community Arts Centre, Stoke Heath, Bromsgrove B60 4JS.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Well done on the exhibition, a mammoth task!
I would like to point out however, that most photographer distinctions in the catalogue and listings are around 3 years out of date. I completely understand how annual updating can be monumental, but gaining distinctions can be a costly, time-consuming and emotive journey, so perhaps it would be better to remove them from the catalogue and listings rather than print incorrectly?
Kind Regards

I agree with Angie's comments above. I travelled up from Surrey for the exhibition, staying overnight to attend the presentations, and was really disappointed that my distinctions were printed in the catalogue out of date despite sending them with my entry and also emailing the Chairman pointing out that they were wrong. I was also quite shocked to see in the PDI show of accepted and awarded images that so many others were wrong.

item.title: 'Haymaking'
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded: Our member, Jill Howe, recently entered a local photography competition at Country Wides stores. Her entry 'Haymaking' was picked as the winning entry at the stores open evening on 10th November. Congratulations Jill! [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="600" caption="Haymaking by Jill Howe"][/caption] See some more of Jill's pictures in our members gallery - just click on the image below. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="600" caption="Members Gallery - Jill Howe"][/caption]

item.title: Going Mobile
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded: From today, if you view the Bromsgrove Photographic Society website from a mobile device, you will see a version optimised for mobile devices. The default view for the mobile website is currently the news page: [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="336" caption="Mobile News"][/caption] A drop down menu giving access to other pages on the website is located on the top right of the screen: [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="337" caption="Mobile Menu"][/caption] If you would like to switch back to the none mobile site, you can turn the mobile version off using the button on the bottom of the webpage. This is still new and will evolve over time, but we hope it will give a better experience to people visiting the website on smartphones and tablets.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: New mobile version of BPS website.

item.title: Midland Bank Trophy 2011
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="600" caption="Herring Fleet Mill by Mal Ogden"][/caption] Last night (7th December) we took part in the annual Midland Bank Trophy. The Midland Bank Trophy is an inter club competition between Bromsgrove, Studley and Redditch. This year, the event was hosted by Studley and judged by Graham Hodgkiss ARPS MPAGB APAGB AFIAP. Each club gets to enter eight prints and eight digital images. Graham scored each image individually with a maximum mark for an image of 20. Four images from Bromsgrove received the maximum 20 points:
  1. Devils Child by Barry Green (print)
  2. Tomb Raider by Barry Green (print)
  3. Annett in Pink by Alan Fackrell (digital)
  4. Herring Fleet Mill by Mal Ogden (digital)
The final scores were:
 
Bromsgrove Studley Redditch
272 225 224
It was a great evening. All the clubs entered some stunning images. Thanks Studley fro hosting the event this year. We look forward to hosting it in 2012. We also created a live twitter stream of the event on the Bromsgrove PS twitter page:http://twitter.com/bromsgrovepsYou can "relive" the event as it happened by reading the tweets below. http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144458798470402048 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144501367803871232 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144501572884373505 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144503911586336768 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144506788790808576 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144507367508291584 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144509256236933120 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144510972139286530 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144512443488542720 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144514212448845824 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144514635817684992 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144514674602426368 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144516543240351744 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144517027288199168 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144519708354428929 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144525231321645057 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144525676450557954 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144525984903872512 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144528685536509952 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144529616172888065 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144530949902843904 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144532159682707457 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144532945552687106 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144533857792827393 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144534722326966275 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144534829231374337 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144535254466699264 http://twitter.com/#!/BromsgrovePS/status/144536099723808768

item.title: The Rat Pack In Bromsgrove
item.dc:creator: Andy Kent
item.content:encoded:
On Sunday 15th January, the Rat Pack Las Vegas Spectacular held a matinee, and evening show at Bromsgroves Artrix. BPS members were invited to come along and photograph the show, and attended both showings. As well as the show itself, BPS were asked to take some shots of the group between the showings, and some shots of them mingling with the punters, and doing signings after the evening show.
The show was fantastic, and a great opportunity to try out a different kind of photography. Members were given the freedom of the theatre to roam around and take shots during the show. The only restrictions being to not be obtrusive and not to use flash. The lighting was constantly changing, and often dark, so balancing exposures to work with spotlit singers and dimly lit backgrounds, along with a continuously changing, and often fast paced scene was very challenging!
A good time was had by all, and I am sure many great photos were taken, maybe a few will show up in the club competitions in the coming months!
Any members who went to the show, please add your photos to the comments below.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great write up Andy, some super Photographs taken, looks like you had a fantastic time,will look forward to seeing more of your shots, Pete

item.title: Hipstamatic
item.dc:creator: Peter Garnett
item.content:encoded: Hipstamatic is a digital photography application for the Apple iPhone. It uses the iPhone's camera to allow you to take square photographs, to which it applies a number of software filters to make the images look as though they were taken with an antique film camera. The user can choose from a number of effects which are presented in the application as simulated lenses, films and flash guns. Several of these are included with the application, others can be bought through an in-app purchase. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="851" caption="Hipstamatic"][/caption] Hipstamatic was designed to emulate a range of toy plastic cameras, strange film types, lenses and processing. These had, and still have in fact, a whole collection of peculiarities. Look at Diana, Holga and Lomo cameras. Some had variable light leakage others had dubious plastic lenses. According to Synthetic, the designers, the Hipstamatic 100 camera was developed in the early 1980s by Bruce and Winston Dorbowski, but was a commercial failure, selling fewer than 200 units. It was supposed to have been an idea that the camera should cost less than the film. The application's styling is based on this kind of cheap, plastic, analogue, photographic camera. It is assumed that this story is pure advertising. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1280" caption="Walk Down the Pier"][/caption] 1.4 million apps were sold up to late 2010. It received additional publicity when New York Times photographer Damon Winter used it, in 2010, to illustrate a front-page story about the Afghanistan War. Winter's images gained recognition by receiving third place in the Pictures of the Year International photojournalism competition. So my second place is nothing new! In the same way that cult brand Lomography is enjoying success with its analogue, film-based, snappers, Hipstamatic is getting the same effect in digital form. There are Flickr sites dedicated to the Hipstamatic and a large online community sharing pictures. Prints can be bought which replicate vintage printing techniques as well. They can, however, be downloaded to your PC and printed out. Maybe youre thinking, But isnt this cheating, theres no real photography here! Well maybe youre wrong. OK, its not a big DSLR, its not a CSC, its not even a compact, its a camera phone for heavens sake. Yes it does do all the fancy photoshoping bits for you and you have no control over that part. What you do have control over is the actual image. You still have to see the picture before you take it. You still have to frame the picture, not always easy in the on screen viewfinder. You have a large range of variables in the type of film, lens and flash you use. Each has their own characteristics and suits different styles of picture. Its still up to you how the final picture turns out. Isnt that the same for film or other digital? You dont get perfect pictures. Some have lens flare, some have light leaks, some are grainy, some have weird cross-processing effects and some arent even too sharp and a bit fuzzy. But thats the fun of it. OK, I wont be submitting these images all the time, just maybe now and again if one comes out as I wanted it to. I checked out printing one of these images and to print it 100%, no resizing, it would need an A2 sheet of paper. A final point. Pros are using iPhones in the same way that they used polaroids. Check back to the third paragraph. If youve got an iPhone, get Hipstamatic. If youve got Android try one of the similar Android apps. Android and Blackberry users, currently, do not a Hipstamatic App for their devices. There are similar apps available but not Hipstamatic. Apparently an Android version is being worked on? Hipstamatics fun, its addictive and, generally, you always have it with you.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Hipstamatic image wins second place in monthly competition!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Who asked the question about photographic authenticity?
A photograph is defined as deriving from the action of light, of any wavelength, on a sensitive surface.
All that Pete describes complies with the definition so it is a photograph. None of the "manipulation" is new, either.
PeterY

item.title: Summer Programme 2012
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded:
Our summer programme is now available! Select "Programme" from the menu above to see details in the regular BPS calendar. Highlights of the summer programme include:

Model Night at Avoncroft MUSEUM of Buildings on 19 June

This annual event is always a great evening, with a number of models and the buildings at Avoncroft providing some great photographic opportunities. This event provided many pictures entered into our competitions over the last year, including this image of Kayleigh by Malcolm Landon.

Coach trip to Portsmouth on 22nd July

Our annual coach trip, this year to Portsmouth. A full days photography, perhaps some of the historic boats in the city will be making an appearance in competitions next year.
"Hipstamatic. Fog Ahoy!" by Kimb0lene License : Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 2.0 Generic (CC BY-NC-ND 2.0) "Spinnaker from the slipway" by PhotoGraham License : Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 2.0 Generic (CC BY-NC-SA 2.0)

Walk and Buffet on 24th July

Put on by one of our members, June, this is the club's social event of the summer - not to be missed. Take a look at the full programme, there are many other great evenings out. Now all we need is some good weather!

item.title: Exhibition at St Michaels Church, Stoke Prior
item.dc:creator: malcyl
item.content:encoded: St Michaels Church, Stoke Prior, is having an open day and Arts and Crafts fair on the weekend of 7th and 8th July . The church warden has invited Bromsgrove Photographic Society to put on a photographic exhibition during the weekend. While planning for the exhibition is still under way, we are hoping to exhibit around 20 to 25 photos, some of which will show the local area. So, if you're in the area, come along and take a look at some of out photographs! [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="600" caption="St Michaels Church, Stoke Prior"][/caption]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: BPS to hold Exhibition of it's work at local church.
